turns.text: Okay
turns.label: o

turns.text: Okay
turns.label: b^m

turns.text: So what do you think about it Should -
turns.label: qo

turns.text: Um I like the idea of nursing homes as as growing choi- the choices you have in nursing homes now whereas used to you used to have only you put you know - when when people got to the point where they were debilitated and couldnt take care of themselves -- -
turns.label: sv

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: -- and there was no other choice You couldnt take them in your own home then they went into nursing home You know maybe you lived too far away to care for them
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Right
turns.label: b

turns.text: or your daily job or whatever prevented it But um I like the choices you have now where they can go into an apartment type setting and have some basically have independent life-style but assisted care
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Yeah
turns.label: b

turns.text: And then if things deteriorate they can go to second level which is you know like where they prepare their meals for them --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: -- and and they still live somewhat independently but they have people checking on them and making sure they have hot meals
turns.label: sv

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: And then where the same community lot of times will also have the third level which is full care you know where some people cant where theyre in wheelchair or where theyre in bed
turns.label: sv

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: and they cant get around but then they have full care But I really like those those options now and and I think about it more often because my husbands parents are theyre very active right now but theyre seventy-five and and seventy-two So that comes up somewhat more often in my thoughts as I see these things --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: -- because of their age
Yes Um its its funny because um I know people at that are in all three and people that work you know I know someone that - works in all three different stages like you said
turns.label: b

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: And I have known you know people close to me that have been in all three and I have seen them like go from where theyre in an apartment building they we call it um - well we have high rises and its just for elderly people you know or most of most of one of their spouses has already passed away
turns.label: sd

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: And its really nice for them because then theyre with people their own age and people that have gone through things exactly what they have gone through
turns.label: sd

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: And its its really nice to go and see them you know where they can still get around and everything and they still you know do their own thing but its its really nice to see them because - I mean sometimes - like I had great aunt she lived with us for um three months and because shes starting to get Alzheimers disease And I know I have bunch of younger brothers and sisters and I know it was hard for me as well as it was for them to to actually sit down because she doesnt like doing things that the younger kids like doing
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Right
turns.label: b

turns.text: And to actually sit so its really nice to see that
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Yeah thats some of the things I would find important before I I would look into that for person is is is like youre saying good mix of people who have the same interests
turns.label: aa

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: And uh and the programs here they have different uh besides just different levels within the same program they have different types of programs They have several areas They have one area in town where the people - I guess lot of it comes with money I this this one area is bit more expensive and the people who probably are living there have had more money in their life But but things that people where they have similar interests
turns.label: sd

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: Like youre saying and the programs that they have where where some of them will have dances once week --
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Yeah
turns.label: b

turns.text: -- and some of them sponsor different crafts and they go to the arboretum to see things and they make sure that if they want to go to church theres bus there
turns.label: sd

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: And itll or you know or someone will transport them to specific church even though its you know maybe its thirty minutes away because its big you know Dallas area is big metropolitan area
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Yeah
turns.label: b

turns.text: But lot of these places have have churches or have have individual transportation Thats thats something Id look for something that would make me happy personally if I had to live there
turns.label: sd

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: Because I dont think lot of people really even in the nice ones and even in the ones where they can live fairly independently they really dont necessarily like it --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Yeah
turns.label: b

turns.text: -- because theyre not in their own home
uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: So I think those kinds of things to make it more homelike and to make it more um enjoyable for them Thatd thatd be one thing Id look for along with the uh health care aspects --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: -- to make sure they had you know that it was clean and that they had good doctors and nurses
Yeah Um Im in college and Im Im only twenty-one but we had spee- I had speech class last semester and there was girl in my class who did speech on home care of the elderly
turns.label: aa

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: And I was so surprised to hear how many people - like whenever theyre in you know the older people theyre like um fastened to their beds so they cant get out just because they you know they wander the halls
turns.label: sd

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: And they get the wrong medicine just because you know the the aides or whoever just give them the wrong medicine
Yeah
turns.label: b

turns.text: And so many of them you know are -
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Are overmedicated too

Yes And it was it was awful to hear what you know what some of these people really went through And I forget the percentage of people that you know that she had said and this was I mean she did research on it and everything
turns.label: aa

turns.text: uh-huh Yeah thats one of the things that that we dont think about as we get older and the the money that it now requires to uh be in one of these places Because some of these people that are just on social security - and if they dont have any living relatives - perhaps they never had children or if their children you know passed away before they did --
turns.label: b

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: -- they can be in some places that are you know that that are not good
Yeah
turns.label: b

turns.text: Or they they have very minimum minimal care and the the care that they are getting the people who are giving it are pro- are paid at minimum wage and they just do- they dont care as much
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Yeah
turns.label: b

turns.text: And and like you said theyre trying to make it the caretakers in some cases are trying to make easy on themselves to the point where theyre putting people in bed or overmedicating them so theyll stay in one spot and not do anything
turns.label: sv

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: That certainly would be something to to watch for Because youve got with some of them being some of these places can even be two and three thousand dollars month to stay in
turns.label: sv

turns.text: I know and some- and sometimes they share room and its just little cubbyhole
turns.label: aa

turns.text: Yeah
turns.label: b

turns.text: and they share it with another person and theyre still paying that much
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Oh yeah so youve -
turns.label: aa

turns.text: It it it just sometimes it just seems ridiculous
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Yeah youve got to really strike balance in what kind of care what kind of level of care you need and then what you can unfortunately what you can afford at the same time
turns.label: aa

turns.text: uh-huh uh-huh yeah Um Ive been lucky well my moms um parents theyre both in their in their uh eighties and I was just home for spring break and my grandma said something to me about she goes well maybe well just sell the house She said its getting too big for us to take care of And I was like no no no stay in the house as long as you can
turns.label: aa

turns.text: Well like there are other communities too that arent necessarily nursing home I had an aunt who lived in small town in Texas that um was in - it was it was housing division Each person had their own little bitty house --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: -- that they had built and it was um supplemented their they were most of them were on social security and they got some kind of supplemental aid besides from the state government But it was this little bitty one bedroom house but it was separate house and they had living room and bedroom and kitchen
Oh
turns.label: b

turns.text: and bathroom So they still had they had and they had people who came in who um supervised th- all these houses were like fifteen or twenty of them all right together kind of like on one block
uh-huh

turns.label: sd

turns.text: It sounds like uh an apartment or som- -
turns.label: sv

Oh
turns.label: b

Yeah

turns.label: sd

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.label: sd

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.text: They had people who did the yard and they had maid that uh uh service that came in and cleaned everybodys house So they didnt have to worry about that
turns.label: sd

turns.label: sd

turns.text: uh-huh
turns.label: b

turns.label: sd
